+Identified in the country in 1987,<ref name=KP301112/> HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive [[epidemic]] emerged among injecting [[Narcotic|drug]] users in the southern and eastern regions of the country.<ref name=usaid/> Ukraine has one of the highest rates of increase of HIV/AIDS cases in [[Eastern Europe]].<ref name=kids>{{cite news|url=http://un.ua/eng/article/166144.html|title=United Nations Registers More Children With AIDS In Ukraine|agency=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=1 December 2008|accessdate=2 December 2008}} {{Dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref>
 
-== Situation ==
+==Situation==
 
-=== Spread of AIDS ===
-HIV officially reached the territory of the former Soviet Union in 1987,<ref name=KP301112/> about 5 years after the virus itself was discovered. Until 1995 there were only a few known cases of HIV infections in Ukraine. The country was therefore deemed to be “low risk” by the World Health Organisation (WHO) in terms of spread at that time.<ref name="Burruano und Seydel">''L. Burruano und J. Seydel'' Die Ausbreitung von HIV/AIDS in der Ukraine. Gesundheitswesen 2006;68, 8-9, 571-574, Georg Thieme Verlag, Stuttgart. ISSN 0941-3790</ref> Between 1987 and 1994, 183 infections were reported.<ref name=bookSTD>[http://books.google.nl/books?id=qe5Edc5EYJEC&pg=PA49&dq=Ukraine+183+infections+were+reported&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=MVC6UNaqLIuY0QX8uYH4AQ&sqi=2&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Ukraine%20183%20infections%20were%20reported&f=false Sexually Transmitted Diseases, Fourth Edition]. [[McGraw-Hill Professional]]. 2007. ISBN 0071417486</ref>
+===Spread of AIDS===
+HIV officially reached the territory of the former Soviet Union in 1987,<ref name=KP301112/> about 5 years after the virus itself was discovered. Until 1995 there were only a few known cases of HIV infections in Ukraine. The country was therefore deemed to be “low risk” by the World Health Organisation (WHO) in terms of spread at that time.<ref name="Burruano und Seydel">''L. Burruano und J. Seydel'' Die Ausbreitung von HIV/AIDS in der Ukraine. Gesundheitswesen 2006;68, 8-9, 571-574, Georg Thieme Verlag, Stuttgart. ISSN 0941-3790</ref> Between 1987 and 1994, 183 infections were reported.<ref name=bookSTD>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.nl/books?id=qe5Edc5EYJEC&pg=PA49&dq=Ukraine+183+infections+were+reported&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=MVC6UNaqLIuY0QX8uYH4AQ&sqi=2&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Ukraine%20183%20infections%20were%20reported&f=false|title=Sexually Transmitted Diseases|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill Professional]]|edition=4th|year=2007|isbn=0071417486}}</ref>
 
 In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} During that time, [[Heterosexuality|heterosexual]] transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and [[perinatal]] transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}}
 [[File:Registered HIV prevalence in Ukraine.jpg|thumb|400px|Registered [[HIV]] [[prevalence]] in Ukraine (late 2007)]]
-[[Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|UNAIDS]] estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every [[Administrative divisions of Ukraine|oblast]] in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts ([[Odessa Oblast|Odessa]], [[Mykolaiv Oblast|Mykolaiv]], [[Dnipropetrovsk Oblast|Dnipropetrovsk]], and [[Donetsk Oblast|Donetsk]]) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/> A major reason for this is the fact that the urbanized and industrialized regions in the East and South of Ukraine suffered most from the economic crisis in the 90s, which in turn led to the spread of unemployment, alcoholism, and drug abuse, thus setting the conditions for wider spread of the epidemic.<ref name="undr">[http://europeandcis.undp.org/rhdr.aids2008/report/hiv_ukraine_en.pdf Vulnerability Assessment of People Living With HIV (PLHIV) in Ukraine] ''[[United Nations Development Programme]], page 24'' - Retrieved on December 08, 2009</ref>
+[[Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|UNAIDS]] estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every [[Administrative divisions of Ukraine|oblast]] in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts ([[Odessa Oblast|Odessa]], [[Mykolaiv Oblast|Mykolaiv]], [[Dnipropetrovsk Oblast|Dnipropetrovsk]], and [[Donetsk Oblast|Donetsk]]) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/> A major reason for this is the fact that the urbanized and industrialized regions in the East and South of Ukraine suffered most from the economic crisis in the 90s, which in turn led to the spread of unemployment, alcoholism, and drug abuse, thus setting the conditions for wider spread of the epidemic.<ref name=undr>[http://europeandcis.undp.org/rhdr.aids2008/report/hiv_ukraine_en.pdf Vulnerability Assessment of People Living With HIV (PLHIV) in Ukraine] ''[[United Nations Development Programme]], page 24'' - Retrieved on 8 December 2009.</ref>
 
 From 1995 to 2007, the primary means of HIV transmission was through injection drug use, but by 2008, sexual contact outpaced injection drug use as the primary form of transmission.<ref name=usaid/> By 2009, almost 44 percent of new infections occurred through sexual transmission, and 36 percent were through injecting drug use (according to [[USAID]]; according to [[Center for Strategic and International Studies|CSIS]] in 2009 the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use was 60%).<ref name=CSISMarch2012>[http://csis.org/publication/injection-drug-use-ukraine Injecting Drug Use in Ukraine], [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] (March 2012)</ref>).<ref name=usaid/> 
 
-In 2007 about 0.96 percent of [[Ukrainians]], or about 440,000 citizens, were estimated to be living with HIV/AIDS,<ref>http://www.unaids.org/en/KnowledgeCentre/HIVData/mapping_progress.asp</ref> down from 1.46 percent of the population in 2005, or 685,600 citizens, according to UNAIDS.<ref name=KyivPost1/> The number of HIV/AIDS cases in Ukraine reduced by 200 or 3.9% to 4,900 in the period of January–November 2008, compared with the corresponding period of last year.In 2007 the majority of those infected where under 30 years of age; with a full 25% of those affected still in their teens.<ref name=UNYouth2007>[http://books.google.nl/books?id=iCBr_yDbqBYC&pg=PA185&dq=%6025%25%60+under+20+Ukraine+AIDS&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=NGK6UOC-NsTW0QX0xYGoAQ&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%6025%25%60%20under%2020%20Ukraine%20AIDS&f=false World Youth Report 2007:Young People's Transition to Adulthood], [[United Nations]], (July 2, 2008)</ref>
+In 2007 about 0.96 percent of [[Ukrainians]], or about 440,000 citizens, were estimated to be living with HIV/AIDS,<ref>http://www.unaids.org/en/KnowledgeCentre/HIVData/mapping_progress.asp</ref> down from 1.46 percent of the population in 2005, or 685,600 citizens, according to UNAIDS.<ref name=KyivPost1/> The number of HIV/AIDS cases in Ukraine reduced by 200 or 3.9% to 4,900 in the period of January–November 2008, compared with the corresponding period of last year.In 2007 the majority of those infected where under 30 years of age; with a full 25% of those affected still in their teens.<ref name=UNYouth2007>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.nl/books?id=iCBr_yDbqBYC&pg=PA185&dq=%6025%25%60+under+20+Ukraine+AIDS&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=NGK6UOC-NsTW0QX0xYGoAQ&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%6025%25%60%20under%2020%20Ukraine%20AIDS&f=false|title=World Youth Report 2007:Young People's Transition to Adulthood|publisher=[[United Nations]]|pager=185|isbn=92-1-130257-9}}</ref>
 
-Although HIV/AIDS had remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it was feared in 2008 it may be spreading to the general population.<ref name="undr"/> According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:HvprziBdLogJ:transition.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf+USAID+Health+Profile+Ukraine+-+November+2010&hl=nl&gl=nl&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjbApo5ati5o-ZAZpYeeOYqoyU1GMEz_sM9v3u9HkvHRCe48IxeYOloIQW-OVcOZNNgskcHHQKc_yK0zDEpMDmejPkW7Lxdobvcz7Y04-gnv9VplsdMRAe7XOnFRG5JOVO00Gje&sig=AHIEtbSDRq-EcaDnIEfeV8FN56LqTPDPIg "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>
+Although HIV/AIDS had remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it was feared in 2008 it may be spreading to the general population.<ref name="undr"/> According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:HvprziBdLogJ:transition.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf+USAID+Health+Profile+Ukraine+-+November+2010&hl=nl&gl=nl&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjbApo5ati5o-ZAZpYeeOYqoyU1GMEz_sM9v3u9HkvHRCe48IxeYOloIQW-OVcOZNNgskcHHQKc_yK0zDEpMDmejPkW7Lxdobvcz7Y04-gnv9VplsdMRAe7XOnFRG5JOVO00Gje&sig=AHIEtbSDRq-EcaDnIEfeV8FN56LqTPDPIg "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Retrieved 7 September 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>
 
 According to the [[Health Ministry of Ukraine]] the HIV infection rate fell by 6.7% and mortality from AIDS was down by 7.9% in 2014.
 <ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237701.html Number of HIV infection cases in Ukraine down by almost 7% since early 2014, says health ministry], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (3 December 2014)</ref>
 
-=== Prisons ===
+===Prisons===
 {{see also|Prisons in Ukraine}}
 Between 1996 and 2001 about 26 percent in various prisons across Ukraine tested HIV- positive. In a January 2005 study between 15 and 30 percent of prisoners tested HIV- positive.<ref name=hepcrate/>
 
-Early 2005 rates of up to 95 percent of the prisoners were found [[Hepatitis C]] positive.<ref name=hepcrate>[http://www.aidslex.org/site_documents/PR-0001E.pdf HIV/AIDS and hepatitis C in prisons: the facts], [[AIDSLEX]] (2006)</ref>
+Early 2005 rates of up to 95 percent of the prisoners were found [[Hepatitis C]] positive.<ref name=hepcrate>[http://www.aidslex.org/site_documents/PR-0001E.pdf HIV/AIDS and hepatitis C in prisons: the facts], [[AIDSLEX]] (2006) Retrieved 1 April 2010.</ref>
 
-Early 2010 there were over 147,000 people held at [[prisons in Ukraine|prisons]] and more than 38,000 at pre-trial detention facilities in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62887/ Number of inmates in Ukraine rises for first time in 7 years], [[Kyiv Post]] (26 March 2009)</ref>
+Early 2010 there were over 147,000 people held at [[prisons in Ukraine|prisons]] and more than 38,000 at pre-trial detention facilities in Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62887/|title=Number of inmates in Ukraine rises for first time in 7 years|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=1 April 2010|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20110131231948/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62887/|archivedate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
 
-=== Spread of AIDS among children ===
+===Spread of AIDS among children===
+The number of children with AIDS in Ukraine is on the rise, since the number of mothers with HIV grows by 20-30% annually. According to the United Nations, the number of pregnant women with HIV was 0.34% in 2007, which was the highest index in Europe. According to the United Nations, of nearly 18,000 children born by HIV-positive mothers in Ukraine, 10,200 children have not contracted HIV and another 5,500 children under eighteen months have yet to receive final results of examination. In Ukraine 1,877 children have been confirmed as HIV positive and 244 have died of AIDS. The United Nations notes that the program of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in Ukraine has cut the share of such transmission from 27% of the number of HIV cases in 2000 to 7% in 2006.<ref name=kids/> According to the [[Health Ministry of Ukraine]] the HIV transmission from mother to a child was 4.28% in 2014 compared to 29% in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237701.html|title=Number of HIV infection cases in Ukraine down by almost 7% since early 2014, says health ministry|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=3 December 2014}}</ref>
 
-The number of children with AIDS in Ukraine is on the rise, since the number of mothers with HIV grows by 20-30% annually. According to the United Nations, the number of pregnant women with HIV was 0.34% in 2007, which was the highest index in Europe. According to the United Nations, of nearly 18,000 children born by HIV-positive mothers in Ukraine, 10,200 children have not contracted HIV and another 5,500 children under eighteen months have yet to receive final results of examination. In Ukraine 1,877 children have been confirmed as HIV positive and 244 have died of AIDS. The United Nations notes that the program of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in Ukraine has cut the share of such transmission from 27% of the number of HIV cases in 2000 to 7% in 2006.<ref name="kids"/> According to the [[Health Ministry of Ukraine]] the HIV transmission from mother to a child was 4.28% in 2014 compared to 29% in 2004.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237701.html Number of HIV infection cases in Ukraine down by almost 7% since early 2014, says health ministry], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (3 December 2014)</ref>
+==Preventive measures==
+From 2001 till June 2015 HIV-positive Ukrainian citizens were barred from travelling abroad and HIV-positive foreigners were forbidden to enter Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|title=Ukraine lifts ban on HIV-positive visitors|agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
 
-== Preventive measures ==
-From 2001 till June 2015 HIV-positive Ukrainian citizens were barred from travelling abroad and HIV-positive foreigners were forbidden to enter Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html Ukraine lifts ban on HIV-positive visitors], [[UNIAN]] (6 August 2015)</ref>
+===Harm reduction programs===
+[[Image:An ambulance in Kiev.jpg|right|thumb|An ambulance in [[Kiev]]]]
+Since 2003, drug substitution programs have been introduced in Ukraine. By the end of September 2008 they were offered to about 2200 persons in 38 locations.<ref name="Alliance">{{cite web|url=http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|title=''Alliance''. International HIV and AIDS Alliance, Kiew|accessdate=1 December 2012|archivedate=6 September 2009|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090906023039/http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp}}</ref> Mostly Buprenorphin (Trademark ‘Subutex‘) is dispensed, which is significantly more expensive than Methadon. It is also less frequently used and thoroughly researched worldwide. Buprenophin is more accepted by society and politicians however, because it is seen as a painkiller. Methadon, in contrast, is viewed as a drug subscribed at public expense.<ref name="Weber">''C. Weber'' Assessment 2007 in Donetsk. http://www.aids-ukraine.org.</ref> 
 
-=== Harm reduction programs ===
-[[Image:An ambulance in Kiev.jpg|right|thumb|An ambulance in [[Kiev]]]]
-Since 2003, drug substitution programs have been introduced in Ukraine. By the end of September 2008 they were offered to about 2200 persons in 38 locations.<ref name="Alliance">''Alliance''. International HIV and AIDS Alliance, Kiew. http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp</ref> Mostly Buprenorphin (Trademark ‘Subutex‘) is dispensed, which is significantly more expensive than Methadon. It is also less frequently used and thoroughly researched worldwide. Buprenophin is more accepted by society and politicians however, because it is seen as a painkiller. Methadon, in contrast, is viewed as a drug subscribed at public expense.<ref name="Weber">''C. Weber'' Assessment 2007 in Donetsk. http://www.aids-ukraine.org.</ref> 
+In 2012 patients and advocacy groups complained of occasional supply shortages in Ukrainian AIDS clinics.<ref name=KP301112>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/hiv-prevention-aids-treatment-still-lags-in-ukraine-316990.html|title=HIV prevention, AIDS treatment still lag in Ukraine|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=30 November 2012|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=AP29612/> In June 2012 advocacy groups accused [[Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)|Health Ministry]] officials of [[Corruption_in_Ukraine#Corruption_in_healthcare|embezzling money]] that should be used to treat [[AIDS patients]] by buying AIDS drugs at hugely inflated prices and then receiving kickbacks.<ref name=AP29612>[http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ukraine-corruption-blamed-aids-non-treatment Ukraine:Corruption blamed for AIDS non-treatment], [[Associated Press]] (29 June 2012)</ref>
 
-In 2012 patients and advocacy groups complained of occasional supply shortages in Ukrainian AIDS clinics.<ref name=KP301112>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/hiv-prevention-aids-treatment-still-lags-in-ukraine-316990.html HIV prevention, AIDS treatment still lag in Ukraine ], [[Kyiv Post]] (30 November 2012)</ref><ref name=AP29612/> In June 2012 advocacy groups accused [[Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)|Health Ministry]] officials of [[Corruption_in_Ukraine#Corruption_in_healthcare|embezzling money]] that should be used to treat [[AIDS patients]] by buying AIDS drugs at hugely inflated prices and then receiving kickbacks.<ref name=AP29612>[http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ukraine-corruption-blamed-aids-non-treatment Ukraine:Corruption blamed for AIDS non-treatment], [[Associated Press]] (29 June 2012)</ref>
-
-== National response ==
-
+==National response==
 The policy and legal environment in [[Ukraine]] is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>
 
 Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>
 
-The first Ukrainian advocate group of/for Ukrainian AIDS patients was launched on December 10, 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93102/ All-Ukrainian Network of people living with HIV: Association of patients established in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 18, 2010)</ref>
+The first Ukrainian advocate group of/for Ukrainian AIDS patients was launched on December 10, 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/all-ukrainian-network-of-people-living-with-hiv-as-93102.html|title=All-Ukrainian Network of people living with HIV: Association of patients established in Ukraine|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=6 January 2016}}</ref>
 
-== Statistics ==

 Note: all statistics till late 2007.

llm_output:
The change made is the addition of citations and reformatting of references throughout the article, specifically in the section discussing the HIV/AIDS epidemic in Ukraine. 

**Justification**: The revisions focus on improving the citation format and ensuring that references are properly attributed, which enhances the credibility and reliability of the information presented. There are no indications of weaponisation in the language or content, as the changes do not introduce biased narratives or politically charged terms.

Not Weaponised

initial_version:
{{wikify}}

==Prevalence==
Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

+Early 2010 there were over 147,000 people held at [[prisons in Ukraine|prisons]] and more than 38,000 at pre-trial detention facilities in Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62887/|title=Number of inmates in Ukraine rises for first time in 7 years|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=1 April 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131231948/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62887/|archivedate=31 January 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
 
 ===Spread of AIDS among children===
 The number of children with AIDS in Ukraine is on the rise, since the number of mothers with HIV grows by 20-30% annually. According to the United Nations, the number of pregnant women with HIV was 0.34% in 2007, which was the highest index in Europe. According to the United Nations, of nearly 18,000 children born by HIV-positive mothers in Ukraine, 10,200 children have not contracted HIV and another 5,500 children under eighteen months have yet to receive final results of examination. In Ukraine 1,877 children have been confirmed as HIV positive and 244 have died of AIDS. The United Nations notes that the program of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in Ukraine has cut the share of such transmission from 27% of the number of HIV cases in 2000 to 7% in 2006.<ref name=kids/> According to the [[Health Ministry of Ukraine]] the HIV transmission from mother to a child was 4.28% in 2014 compared to 29% in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237701.html|title=Number of HIV infection cases in Ukraine down by almost 7% since early 2014, says health ministry|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=3 December 2014}}</ref>
 
 ==Preventive measures==
-From 2001 till June 2015 HIV-positive Ukrainian citizens were barred from travelling abroad and HIV-positive foreigners were forbidden to enter Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|title=Ukraine lifts ban on HIV-positive visitors|agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
+From 2001 till June 2015 HIV-positive Ukrainian citizens were barred from travelling abroad and HIV-positive foreigners were forbidden to enter Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|title=Ukraine lifts ban on HIV-positive visitors|agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150823140043/http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|archivedate=23 August 2015|df=}}</ref>
 
 ===Harm reduction programs===
 [[Image:An ambulance in Kiev.jpg|right|thumb|An ambulance in [[Kiev]]]]
-Since 2003, drug substitution programs have been introduced in Ukraine. By the end of September 2008 they were offered to about 2200 persons in 38 locations.<ref name="Alliance">{{cite web|url=http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|title=''Alliance''. International HIV and AIDS Alliance, Kiew|accessdate=1 December 2012|archivedate=6 September 2009|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090906023039/http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp}}</ref> Mostly Buprenorphin (Trademark ‘Subutex‘) is dispensed, which is significantly more expensive than Methadon. It is also less frequently used and thoroughly researched worldwide. Buprenophin is more accepted by society and politicians however, because it is seen as a painkiller. Methadon, in contrast, is viewed as a drug subscribed at public expense.<ref name="Weber">''C. Weber'' Assessment 2007 in Donetsk. http://www.aids-ukraine.org.</ref>

initial_version:
{{wikify}}

==Prevalence==
Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts ([[Odessa Oblast|Odessa]], [[Mykolaiv Oblast|Mykolaiv]], [[Dnipropetrovsk Oblast|Dnipropetrovsk]], and [[Donetsk Oblast|Donetsk]]) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/> A major reason for this is the fact that the urbanized and industrialized regions in the East and South of Ukraine suffered most from the economic crisis in the 90s, which in turn led to the spread of unemployment, alcoholism, and drug abuse, thus setting the conditions for wider spread of the epidemic.<ref name=undr>[http://europeandcis.undp.org/rhdr.aids2008/report/hiv_ukraine_en.pdf Vulnerability Assessment of People Living With HIV (PLHIV) in Ukraine] ''[[United Nations Development Programme]], page 24'' - Retrieved on 8 December 2009.</ref>
 
 From 1995 to 2007, the primary means of HIV transmission was through injection drug use, but by 2008, sexual contact outpaced injection drug use as the primary form of transmission.<ref name=usaid/> By 2009, almost 44 percent of new infections occurred through sexual transmission, and 36 percent were through injecting drug use (according to [[USAID]]; according to [[Center for Strategic and International Studies|CSIS]] in 2009 the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use was 60%).<ref name=CSISMarch2012>[http://csis.org/publication/injection-drug-use-ukraine Injecting Drug Use in Ukraine], [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] (March 2012)</ref>).<ref name=usaid/>
 
@@ -35,21 +35,21 @@
 Early 2010 there were over 147,000 people held at [[prisons in Ukraine|prisons]] and more than 38,000 at pre-trial detention facilities in Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62887/|title=Number of inmates in Ukraine rises for first time in 7 years|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=1 April 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131231948/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62887/|archivedate=31 January 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
 
 ===Spread of AIDS among children===
-The number of children with AIDS in Ukraine is on the rise, since the number of mothers with HIV grows by 20-30% annually. According to the United Nations, the number of pregnant women with HIV was 0.34% in 2007, which was the highest index in Europe. According to the United Nations, of nearly 18,000 children born by HIV-positive mothers in Ukraine, 10,200 children have not contracted HIV and another 5,500 children under eighteen months have yet to receive final results of examination. In Ukraine 1,877 children have been confirmed as HIV positive and 244 have died of AIDS. The United Nations notes that the program of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in Ukraine has cut the share of such transmission from 27% of the number of HIV cases in 2000 to 7% in 2006.<ref name=kids/> According to the [[Health Ministry of Ukraine]] the HIV transmission from mother to a child was 4.28% in 2014 compared to 29% in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237701.html|title=Number of HIV infection cases in Ukraine down by almost 7% since early 2014, says health ministry|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=3 December 2014}}</ref>
+The number of children with AIDS in Ukraine is on the rise since the number of mothers with HIV grows by 20-30% annually. According to the United Nations, the number of pregnant women with HIV was 0.34% in 2007, which was the highest index in Europe. According to the United Nations, of nearly 18,000 children born by HIV-positive mothers in Ukraine, 10,200 children have not contracted HIV and another 5,500 children under eighteen months have yet to receive final results of an examination. In Ukraine, 1,877 children have been confirmed as HIV positive and 244 have died of AIDS. The United Nations notes that the program of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in Ukraine has cut the share of such transmission from 27% of the number of HIV cases in 2000 to 7% in 2006.<ref name=kids/> According to the [[Health Ministry of Ukraine]] the HIV transmission from mother to a child was 4.28% in 2014 compared to 29% in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237701.html|title=Number of HIV infection cases in Ukraine down by almost 7% since early 2014, says health ministry|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=3 December 2014}}</ref>
 
 ==Preventive measures==
 From 2001 till June 2015 HIV-positive Ukrainian citizens were barred from travelling abroad and HIV-positive foreigners were forbidden to enter Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|title=Ukraine lifts ban on HIV-positive visitors|agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150823140043/http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|archivedate=23 August 2015|df=}}</ref>
 
 ===Harm reduction programs===
 [[Image:An ambulance in Kiev.jpg|right|thumb|An ambulance in [[Kiev]]]]
-Since 2003, drug substitution programs have been introduced in Ukraine. By the end of September 2008 they were offered to about 2200 persons in 38 locations.<ref name="Alliance">{{cite web|url=http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|title=''Alliance''. International HIV and AIDS Alliance, Kiew|accessdate=1 December 2012|archivedate=6 September 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906023039/http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Mostly Buprenorphin (Trademark ‘Subutex‘) is dispensed, which is significantly more expensive than Methadon. It is also less frequently used and thoroughly researched worldwide. Buprenophin is more accepted by society and politicians however, because it is seen as a painkiller. Methadon, in contrast, is viewed as a drug subscribed at public expense.<ref name="Weber">''C. Weber'' Assessment 2007 in Donetsk. http://www.aids-ukraine.org.</ref>
+Since 2003, drug substitution programs have been introduced in Ukraine. By the end of September 2008, they were offered to about 2200 persons in 38 locations.<ref name="Alliance">{{cite web|url=http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|title=''Alliance''. International HIV and AIDS Alliance, Kiew|accessdate=1 December 2012|archivedate=6 September 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906023039/http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Mostly Buprenorphine (Trademark ‘Subutex‘) is dispensed, which is significantly more expensive than Methadon. It is also less frequently used and thoroughly researched worldwide. Buprenophin is more accepted by society and politicians, however, because it is seen as a painkiller. Methadone, in contrast, is viewed as a drug subscribed at public expense.<ref name="Weber">''C. Weber'' Assessment 2007 in Donetsk. http://www.aids-ukraine.org.</ref>
 
 In 2012 patients and advocacy groups complained of occasional supply shortages in Ukrainian AIDS clinics.<ref name=KP301112>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/hiv-prevention-aids-treatment-still-lags-in-ukraine-316990.html|title=HIV prevention, AIDS treatment still lag in Ukraine|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=30 November 2012|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=AP29612/> In June 2012 advocacy groups accused [[Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)|Health Ministry]] officials of [[Corruption in Ukraine#Corruption in healthcare|embezzling money]] that should be used to treat [[AIDS patients]] by buying AIDS drugs at hugely inflated prices and then receiving kickbacks.<ref name=AP29612>[http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ukraine-corruption-blamed-aids-non-treatment Ukraine:Corruption blamed for AIDS non-treatment], [[Associated Press]] (29 June 2012)</ref>
 
 In the [[War in Donbass]] the separatist authorities of the [[Donetsk People's Republic]] and [[Luhansk People's Republic]] have banned [[methadone]] and [[substitution therapy]] and have taken a hard line on drug addiction and have banned most international medical organizations.<ref name="RFEaiscaUb"/> As a result people living with HIV/AIDS fled separatist-controlled areas.<ref name="RFEaiscaUb">{{cite news |url=http://www.rferl.org/media/photogallery/internally-displaced-women-living-with-hiv/27873176.html |title=HIV: East Ukraine's Silent Crisis|publisher= [[Radio Free Europe]] |date=22 July 2016 }}</ref>
 
 ==National response==
-The policy and legal environment in [[Ukraine]] is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing the capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>
 
 Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

The change made in this revision is the rephrasing of several sentences for clarity and grammatical accuracy, specifically in the sections discussing the spread of AIDS in Ukraine. For example, "the transmission was primarily through injecting drug use" was changed to "transmission was primarily through injecting drug use," and similar adjustments were made throughout the text.

Not Weaponised – The changes are primarily grammatical and stylistic, with no introduction of weaponised narratives or terms related to cultural heritage.

initial_version:
{{wikify}}

==Prevalence==
Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

initial_version:
{{wikify}}

==Prevalence==
Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

initial_version:
{{wikify}}

==Prevalence==
Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

initial_version:
{{wikify}}

==Prevalence==
Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

 ===Spread of AIDS among children===
 The number of children with AIDS in Ukraine is on the rise since the number of mothers with HIV grows by 20-30% annually. According to the United Nations, the number of pregnant women with HIV was 0.34% in 2007, which was the highest index in Europe. According to the United Nations, of nearly 18,000 children born by HIV-positive mothers in Ukraine, 10,200 children have not contracted HIV and another 5,500 children under eighteen months have yet to receive final results of an examination. In Ukraine, 1,877 children have been confirmed as HIV positive and 244 have died of AIDS. The United Nations notes that the program of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in Ukraine has cut the share of such transmission from 27% of the number of HIV cases in 2000 to 7% in 2006.<ref name=kids/> According to the [[Health Ministry of Ukraine]] the HIV transmission from mother to a child was 4.28% in 2014 compared to 29% in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237701.html|title=Number of HIV infection cases in Ukraine down by almost 7% since early 2014, says health ministry|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=3 December 2014}}</ref>
 
 ==Preventive measures==
-From 2001 till June 2015 HIV-positive Ukrainian citizens were barred from travelling abroad and HIV-positive foreigners were forbidden to enter Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|title=Ukraine lifts ban on HIV-positive visitors|agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150823140043/http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|archivedate=23 August 2015|df=}}</ref>
+From 2001 till June 2015 HIV-positive Ukrainian citizens were barred from travelling abroad and HIV-positive foreigners were forbidden to enter Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|title=Ukraine lifts ban on HIV-positive visitors|agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150823140043/http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|archivedate=23 August 2015}}</ref>
 
 ===Harm reduction programs===
 [[Image:An ambulance in Kiev.jpg|right|thumb|An ambulance in [[Kiev]]]]
-Since 2003, drug substitution programs have been introduced in Ukraine. By the end of September 2008, they were offered to about 2200 persons in 38 locations.<ref name="Alliance">{{cite web|url=http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|title=''Alliance''. International HIV and AIDS Alliance, Kiew|accessdate=1 December 2012|archivedate=6 September 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906023039/http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Mostly Buprenorphine (Trademark ‘Subutex‘) is dispensed, which is significantly more expensive than Methadon. It is also less frequently used and thoroughly researched worldwide. Buprenophin is more accepted by society and politicians, however, because it is seen as a painkiller. Methadone, in contrast, is viewed as a drug subscribed at public expense.<ref name="Weber">''C. Weber'' Assessment 2007 in Donetsk. http://www.aids-ukraine.org.</ref>
+Since 2003, drug substitution programs have been introduced in Ukraine. By the end of September 2008, they were offered to about 2200 persons in 38 locations.<ref name="Alliance">{{cite web|url=http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|title=''Alliance''. International HIV and AIDS Alliance, Kiew|accessdate=1 December 2012|archivedate=6 September 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906023039/http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|url-status=dead}}</ref> Mostly Buprenorphine (Trademark ‘Subutex‘) is dispensed, which is significantly more expensive than Methadon. It is also less frequently used and thoroughly researched worldwide. Buprenophin is more accepted by society and politicians, however, because it is seen as a painkiller. Methadone, in contrast, is viewed as a drug subscribed at public expense.<ref name="Weber">''C. Weber'' Assessment 2007 in Donetsk. http://www.aids-ukraine.org.</ref>
 
 In 2012 patients and advocacy groups complained of occasional supply shortages in Ukrainian AIDS clinics.<ref name=KP301112>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/hiv-prevention-aids-treatment-still-lags-in-ukraine-316990.html|title=HIV prevention, AIDS treatment still lag in Ukraine|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=30 November 2012|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=AP29612/> In June 2012 advocacy groups accused [[Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)|Health Ministry]] officials of [[Corruption in Ukraine#Corruption in healthcare|embezzling money]] that should be used to treat [[AIDS patients]] by buying AIDS drugs at hugely inflated prices and then receiving kickbacks.<ref name=AP29612>[http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ukraine-corruption-blamed-aids-non-treatment Ukraine:Corruption blamed for AIDS non-treatment], [[Associated Press]] (29 June 2012)</ref>

initial_version:
{{wikify}}

==Prevalence==
Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

initial_version:
{{wikify}}

==Prevalence==
Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

initial_version:
{{wikify}}

==Prevalence==
Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. First identified in the country in 1987, HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population of foreign students until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive epidemic emerged among injecting drug users in the southern and eastern regions of the country. UNAIDS estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected, or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every oblast in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts (Odessa, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrosvsk, and Donestsk) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/>

In the mid-1990s, transmission was primarily through injecting drug use. By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997. During that time, heterosexual transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and perinatal transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases. Although HIV/AIDS has to date remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it may be spreading to the general population. The majority of those infected are under 30 years of age; a full 25% of those affected are still in their teens.<ref name=usaid/>

Among the issues driving the HIV/AIDS epidemic are high levels of migration and transactional sex; widespread stigma and discrimination (which prevent injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, and other marginalized people from seeking and receiving prevention and treatment interventions); inadequate health and other social services; rising rates of tuberculosis, sexually transmitted infections, and substance abuse; and a general lack of information about the kinds of risky behaviors that contribute to HIV/AIDS. According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Accessed September 7, 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>

==National response==
The policy and legal environment in Ukraine is generally favorable for combating the spread of HIV/AIDS, but there is a gap between national-level policies and laws and local-level practices. The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>

Although the HIV/AIDS law is one of the most progressive in the region, the government still treats HIV/AIDS primarily as a medical issue. Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>

==References==
{{reflist}}
